No matter how much I forget about them or how caught up with work and life I am to notice, they are there, unwavering, unopposed, and unphased by life’s tribulations. Then on days when I am the most stressed and wound, they demand to be seen, and when I turn to them they let me rest my anxious soul, lending me some strength to go on, one day at a time. I first moved here when I started my undergrad, and the mountains to the north of campus where what first captivated me. Sure, the university has its own share of breathtaking sights in buildings and ponds and trees, which have their own share of my heart, but it’s the mountains that really holds its throne. The rest of the town is beautiful in its own right. There are countless cafés that were home to many hours of caffeine fueled cramming. One can walk or take the bus just a little further to the downtown area and be enveloped in an aura of antiquity by the faded colored bricks that line restaurants and office buildings. It is here that this seemingly suburban town shows as much bustle and vigor as it’s neighboring urban city. This doesn’t last for many blocks though, as one can escape, once again, to the serene small town by passing the library. This dichotomy of atmospheres in such proximity truly give this city a wonderous vibe as if it was beckoning to be explored. With this, it is easy to create many a cherished memory, each in association with a certain part of town. Whether it is walking past the rusted swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or running through the busy downtown to catch the movie in the fancy theater for which the university provided tickets. Alas, it is also home to many harsh memories, as all places are bound to be in life. The ponds, in particular, can be a rather fitting place for reflection as well as crying sessions at two in the morning in the middle of an existential crisis. The latter of which, I have more experience in. While watching the turtles and ducks and insects live out their lives, each with some contribution or role, I couldn’t help but wonder about my own sense of purpose as I struggled to navigate this mystery called life. So, I walked past the pond, and past the park and little houses that scream of suburbia, until I reached a main street. It was then that sun shined its brilliant rays atop the palm trees, painting the sky along the way, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, they were there, as they had always been. The sturdy overbearing mountains grazed the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building in the horizon, and as if speaking without words, stirred in me my sense of perseverance.
You might pass it up on first glance - after all, it is a residential area behind a shopping strip, not a place one would assume there are places to live. At least, not places most people would want to live. But if you go behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk back behind the hotels which are only occupied annually aside from a few stints in the summertime for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. Within these communities, on these streets, are a handful of apartment complex - situated next to each other carefully like Russian nesting dolls that have been scrupulously, carefully taken apart and set beside each other in a line down the road, piecemeal. The first apartments you come upon are ones which have been on the news for some fairly unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on those too much - appearances, after all, can be deceiving. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from those complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days attendance is higher. The road t-bones into another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
transformed_texts: I live in rural America, specifically in a small town in Michigan. Here, you transition from farmland to small tourist towns. There are no big city malls, no Wal-Mart, Target, or even an Applebee's. To go anywhere, you have to drive. Despite this, I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world, surrounded by water. My "city" is encircled by water, with beautiful Lake Michigan on one side and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go, there is a beach where you can dip your toes. My neighborhood embodies the small-town concept. Houses aren't built close together, nor are they cookie-cutter homes; they are older, with some being updated and remodeled, while others remain as they were. Most homes have basements—full basements visible from the street. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. In the blocks around my house, there are houses in every imaginable color. Most of them have yards, with trampolines and playsets. Some people have gardens and fences for their animals. The houses reflect Middle America, with hardworking people making a living and either raising families or having raised families. Any day, you'll see kids running up and down the streets. You'll also see people walking dogs, cycling, and rollerblading. Neighbors know each other, and you can tell who belongs and who doesn't. You might see someone grilling outside and wave, or someone walking their dog from a few blocks away and exchange a friendly smile. The lawns are well-kept; no one has leaves piled up from the fall. The green grass is mowed and under control. If there are plants and bushes in the yards, they are kept trimmed. It's not a stunning neighborhood where you drive in and think, wow, look at the nice homes, but rather one where you feel it would be a good place to raise a family. It's quiet, peaceful, and safe. While it looks average, it is exceptional because it represents what people want in the world: a safe place to settle at the end of the day. Within walking distance, there is the county sheriff's department and jail. The health department is right next to it. The city recycling center is just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the area use the services provided. We have nearby baseball and softball fields where you can hear the announcers calling scores and players' names. Our small town airport is next door. You can be outside or even inside and hear the rumble of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local shop, and if you're really up for it, you can make it downtown from our neighborhood. My kids can ride their bikes to the park, which is only about 8 blocks away. It's truly a great place to live.

The area where I live is typical cookie-cutter suburbia. In my neighborhood, the presence of a homeowner's association is very evident. Upon entering, you'll see only well-maintained single-family homes, thanks to the homeowner's association. The front yards are quite similar, with a small patch of landscaped grass, decorative pebbles, and short driveways. Occasionally, you'll notice small trees. Everyone has a two-car garage. As you drive through the neighborhood, you'll notice newly paved concrete. Despite many families living here, the roads are in excellent condition, free of potholes. Most houses are single-story, but there are some two-story ones as well. We don't have the usual mailbox setup you'd expect for single-family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house; instead, there's a grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street, like in apartments. Everyone uses a key for their specific mailbox, and there are two larger lockers for packages. The HOA's obsession with uniformity is evident here. My house is on the edge of the nearby city, so the neighborhood is part rural, part suburbs. We have plenty of land for everything. There are several community pools accessible to residents, well-maintained and gated. Various walking trails allow you to walk your dog or take an evening stroll. You don't need to go to a park for exercise; the neighborhood is large enough for running. Most of the community is retired people. It's a very safe area, and people look out for each other. We also have some middle-aged and young professionals. The city is surprisingly large by population but has a small-town feel. We have most amenities you expect. We have one mall, not huge but sufficient. It takes about 15 minutes to drive anywhere significant, but plenty of stores await when you get there. From high-end grocery stores with organic food to discount outlets with limited items and minimal staff, we have it all. Overall, the neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and typical. We enjoy nice features like pools and walking trails. Although we're not next to shopping, you can drive to any major chain you like.

The first time I heard about my place, I was listening to a podcast about missing people. It was rather surprising. Nearly every apartment in the area was renting for over a thousand dollars a month. I had never heard anything about that story, nor had any of my friends. Maybe it's the struggle. I know some of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Things are expensive, but over the years we've learned how to be thrifty. You begin to appreciate the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. As an adult, you notice smells less. You might start smoking, or maybe you're just too accustomed to the way things are. But the flea market always makes its presence known. The smell of adulthood is dusty magazines piled on a closed piano. It embeds itself in the leather and stays even after washing. Here, there are three thrift stores within walking distance. If you start on the far side, you can visit two charity thrift stores, a library, a rare book shop, and a curio store. Downtown is bustling, with cars and people filling the streets every morning, but you'd never hear it inside the thrift stores. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the store remains silent. It's a nice place to lose an afternoon. Each year, there are more and more of them. Cars and people flood in. They say it's a developing city. It hosts one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery, yet it still shows growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everyone and everything is focused on their own goals, and not much is expected from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you alone. It's not like the South, where being a bit concerned means you care. Here, you don't pry into anyone's life. You can keep up your shell as long as you want, and the city will crash and roll back like waves on the beach. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur singers upstairs, there's always something happening. In a way, we have less of an apartment of strangers and more of a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors, and they treat me well. I try to make sure to clean up after myself and leave them food, and they do the same in return. I bring them mail, and they bring it to me. It's nice to see them, and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I enjoy theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl, but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I haven't completely ruined my life.

I live in a small Midwestern town just beyond the suburbs of a major city. My immediate neighborhood, located on the east side of town, can be described as the most economically disadvantaged area here. Property values are low, with most houses being rented or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is neither unattractive nor unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who greet me with a smile and a hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates, although slightly higher than in other parts of town, remain generally low. In the past ten years, some violent crimes have occurred a few blocks from my home, including shootings and at least one homicide. Our next-door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside a local bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime, except for occasionally having an item disappear from our porch if we forget to bring it in. Overall, the town I live in has been deeply affected by the "opioid epidemic" that has impacted many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive features. My son's elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to teachers and support staff. Despite his special needs, he has not faced any bullying so far due to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town's population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, ensuring no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as "less than" due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The city council and staff have made numerous improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have been made in the town center and on the west side, where all the shopping areas are located and most traffic passes through. The east side where I live is often neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are excellent, there are sufficient shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family's needs, and while our home may not be worth much, it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.

My neighborhood is rich in culture. It's located on a hill, surrounded by buildings of historical significance. I live in a seven-story apartment building right across from the old live theater, and a block down the hill, there's a cool little arcade bar that attracts all kinds of people on warm summer nights. Often, especially on weekends in June and July, you'll see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's quite large considering its location. The park is encircled by concrete, with tall stairs built into the wall. During the cold winter months, homeless people set up their tents in neat rows along the sidewalk and wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the heavy downpours in the middle of winter often make it hard to stay warm. By setting their tents close together in the town center rather than out in the jungle, they stay much warmer. They're also within a reasonable walking and transport distance to the only family center for miles, where they can wash and shower. What I love about my city, though, isn't the beauty of the historic nature—the tall proud buildings, the architecture scattered throughout the varying levels of hills rolling down towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of its people. You see, Hilltop was once the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. You still hear stories, even three decades later, about federal officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean up the streets. The people, they don't forget. Stories are still passed down from generation to generation, even to newcomers like me, from those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the tougher neighborhoods in the entire city, to keep it tidy. They still care about what happens in their city, on their street. They say if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. I truly believe this warning echoes the old days and is tinged with the bitter taste of social conditioning. Perhaps I'm just dark enough not to be seen entirely as a "white girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone just as painfully aware of the constant reminders that plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are born out of ignorance and fear, even in a city supposed to be a cultural melting pot utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have more often and rarely maliciously offered me a jacket than tried to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners stayed open just a few minutes longer so I could charge my phone when I had nowhere to escape the rain. It's a place where I've sat, believing myself invisible, huddled against concrete storefronts on the grayest, dreariest of nights, only for someone to stop, look me in the eye, hand me $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.

I moved to this neighborhood right before starting eighth grade. Initially, I found it difficult to make friends, but eventually, I became close to a girl who lived two houses away and a guy from my street. Neither of them lives there now, but the memories remain. Most of the people who were here when I moved in are still around. My neighborhood is quite similar to a typical American suburban area, with many two-story houses. Every weekend or whenever it's warm, I hear kids playing outside. The neighborhood is quiet most days. I've never had any issues with anyone here; you're left alone unless you need help. I've ordered many packages online, and none have ever been stolen from my porch. I feel I can trust my neighbors. There's a park a minute or two from my house, which holds many memories for me. I've played basketball, football, and baseball there with other neighborhood guys. I also have one of my worst memories from there when I got elbowed in the nose playing football, but the good memories outweigh the bad. Nowadays, I go to that park to spend time with my cousin's kids. They are much younger and love playing on swings and slides. Just the thought of going to the park excites them. The park now makes me nostalgic for various reasons. The neighborhood is very diverse, and you can find all kinds of food nearby. Within a mile, you can find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants. However, many people now use apps like GrubHub and DoorDash for food delivery. Fast food places are the most popular, but you find those in nearly every suburban neighborhood. There are also plenty of pizza places. The stores here have everything you need. Several dry cleaners are nearby. There’s a Walgreens and a CVS on the same street, along with a Jewel-Osco grocery store, which is popular in the Midwest. Some stores are diverse, like an Indian-owned store for anyone in the mood for homemade or ready-made Indian food. Overall, I am a fan of my neighborhood. Reading social media and seeing the news about the horror stories others face with their neighbors makes me grateful for mine.

My neighborhood is close to the college I attend, and because of that, I really enjoy living there. There are mainly apartment buildings, but also a few restaurants and bars that are fun and not too expensive. One of the bars was recently renamed, and it's more expensive, but the service and drinks aren't of the worst quality. Most people are nice. They are either students or have a lower income since the apartment rent isn't very high. There are many children nearby as there's an elementary school within walking distance of my apartment. I don't know my neighbors, but I don't really want to. They smoke a lot of weed, so the management of my building put an air freshener unit right across from their door, which my boyfriend and I found very amusing. It's almost insulting. The buildings around me usually look quite old but might have renovated interiors. A bit down the street, there are brand new apartments, but I don't like them because I know the construction wasn't particularly good. They're cheaply built, but the rent is expensive, which I think is a scam. But since they're near the campus, the building managers can get away with it. There's a really cheap restaurant about five minutes from where I live that serves food only on paper plates, and most of what they make is microwaved. Across from that is a gas station, which I've heard isn't a very good place to work. But thanks to some city funds, the road was redone last summer, so now there's a nice wide sidewalk, lots of grass on the medians and sides of the roads, and the area looks a bit nicer now. However, the apartment building I live in is surrounded by trees. They've cut a few down, so there are a few stumps, but there are far more trees where I live than further down the street. Behind my apartment complex is a tree line and then another set of apartments. I live on 42nd street, but right behind is 43rd street, and that one isn't as nice. The sidewalks are really bad and falling apart, and most of the buildings on it look shabby. There are a lot of trees on this street, but that's probably to hide what the buildings look like. Most of the crime in my area has occurred in an apartment complex on that street, but then again, I can't just blame them. There are apartments across the street from me that also have a lot of crime and a rather transient population. But I think I like where I live. I can afford it, and there are plenty of useful amenities nearby. I especially appreciate that the university is within walking distance, and there are two bus stops so I can easily get to the store and downtown.

My neighborhood consists of duplex houses located on a cul-de-sac. They are spaced and positioned to look like individual homes. The only difference is that each one is painted yellow with white porches and green metal roofs. Almost everyone, though not all, are friends with one another. On some evenings, we gather at the end of an unassigned driveway and chat while the neighborhood's young children play with their toys, sidewalk chalk, or fly their kites. It's very refreshing in this modern, overly mechanical and computer-filled world. It's like stepping back in time. We are surrounded by fields and trees, enhanced by blue skies and white, billowing clouds. The only downside? This season, we are experiencing tornado warnings, and for the first time last night, we actually heard tornado sirens, so we had to seek shelter. Sure enough, you would have found me in my bathtub, clutching my smallest dog along with my purse and a few pillows. My big dog wanted nothing to do with the bathroom and stayed in the living room, nervous and barking due to the strange circumstances. The neighborhood was quiet except for the sound of large hailstones hitting the ground. After the storm, the road literally steamed due to the change in temperature. We went from 92 to 75 degrees in a matter of minutes. The hail melted instantly upon hitting the hot pavement. As I looked up at the clearing sky, the sun came out and it started to rain. A double rainbow appeared. I ran into the house and grabbed my camera, quickly snapping photos to share with my Facebook friends and family. They were amazed, as was I. The streets remained quiet for another hour before some people finally returned home from wherever they had been when the thunderstorm struck. Then it was back to normal, with moms and kids outside while dinner cooked. This is such a friendly neighborhood for someone like me who recently moved from NH to NC. I adore the southern accent people speak with. I have a two-bedroom, two-bath apartment, as does everyone here. Although all the houses look the same on the outside, not all the apartments are the same inside. Some are quite small. That doesn't make sense to me. I love walking along the largest field behind where I live and strolling down to the pond that isn't meant for swimming. I've seen deer, and in the morning, you can hear the giant bullfrog singing its song. It's a fantastic place to live, just forty minutes outside the city of Charlotte. Each morning is greeted by the crowing of roosters from the surrounding farms. It's like living in a small village community of its own. We even have a donkey at a nearby farm that you can hear braying in the evening, letting us know he's there. I was fortunate to find this gem of a neighborhood.

Well, considering I've been here for about 10 years, I think I can share what I know. Initially, I was quite sad when I first arrived in my neighborhood. I moved from Riverdale to Stockbridge, and I won’t lie, I cried because I missed them and loved them... but my mom and dad wanted the best for me and my little sister, so we moved to a better place for housing, a better high school, where everything was considered "not ghetto" when we moved to our new neighborhood. Over the years, I got used to it and made some new friends, and a few new enemies at school too. I never really got to know my neighbors over the years, except for Mr. Glen and his children, and Dennis for a while, both of whom lived right next to us. They were enjoyable people who I can almost consider family in some ways, and I truly appreciate them. I remember when my mom, dad, sister, and I went to Mr. Glen’s wedding (they got re-married). It was really fun and enjoyable, to say the least, and something I look forward to someday, as I build my wealth and give my future wife the life of a Queen. When Mr. Glen’s wife, Ms. Veda, took off the little white strap on her leg and threw it, I caught it! Unfortunately, I didn’t catch the flowers! We danced the night away, and I really enjoyed having a good time with Marsharii, one of their daughters. I haven’t seen her since then. I hope she has moved on to bigger and better things. The neighborhood itself is like a maze, although now I have a GPS, so I can take more time to explore it. I've only ventured so far, and that was when I hung out with my friends Kason and Curtis. We all used to play video games a lot and enjoyed life as much as we could. Sometimes I would go to the park and enjoy nature, which soothes my soul. It gives me a sense of calmness and peace these days. I also bring some sticks that I bought from Home Depot and practice my balance, and bring my bokken wooden sword if I can. I have fun doing what I love. There’s also a basketball and tennis court, although I haven’t played tennis or basketball in a long time, it’s still nice to have in case I ever want to pick it up again. My dad raised me and my best friend on tennis with Mr. Graves, and we’d always have a great time. They worked us hard! But we always had fun. I guess there are a lot of times I’ve had fun in this neighborhood, and there are plenty of stories, but these are the ones that really stood out to me, and I believe the best is yet to come!

My neighborhood is a charming little town. It doesn't differ much from others in South Carolina, but it has a significant influence on the agricultural sector. Johnston is known as the Peach Capital of the World, something the town proudly displays on the welcome sign. It's mainly made up of farmland dominated by peach trees or livestock. Houses outside the main part of town are widely spaced apart; most are two-story with either metal roofs to combat the scorching summer heat or gray shingles. These houses are often set back from the road, allowing the front fields to be used for animals or crops. In the main part of town, there's a single traffic light at a four-way intersection. This is where the only stores in the entire town are located. There are three places to get "fast food": Hong Kong, a small Chinese restaurant run by a single family, Fiesta Mexican Restaurant, or Gary's, a small burger chain. There used to be a pizzeria, but it closed recently. There is a very small family-owned pharmacy called Maxwell and Halford Drug; amusingly, they are best known for the Cherry Coca-Cola they sell. There's a small but pricey grocery store called Independent Grocers Alliance, better known as IGA. Although it's the only grocery store in town, many people stop by just to pick up one or two items; most prefer to travel to a Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville to purchase the bulk of their groceries. The most popular store in town is Dollar General; this store sells a wide range of everyday items and is often busy from opening to closing! There's a very small furniture store, Possibilities Furniture & More, run by a kind woman well-known in the community. The store has been in Johnston for many years and even employs two movers who deliver the purchased furniture! Attached to the furniture store building is a small pet groomer called Clark's Cuts and Kennels. They offer a variety of services like daycare, boarding, grooming, nail grinding, bathing, etc. Both a doctor's and a veterinary practice are located away from the main part of town; they are both very small practices but well-equipped to assist the residents of Johnston. There is a single elementary school called Johnston Elementary School. After completing fifth grade, students must attend both middle and high school in the next town. Technically, there are no parks within the town, but they are currently in the process of creating a 2.5-acre recreational area to provide families with more outing opportunities and attract more visitors or potential residents. Admittedly, there isn't much to do; there are no movie theaters, bowling alleys, "hangout" spots, playgrounds for children, places to walk pets, or a wide variety of restaurants. Despite this, it's a nice town, so small you could pass through in the blink of an eye without realizing it!

I reside in a typical suburban area in a small southern town in Tennessee. It's a street that connects two state highways, so there's a bit more traffic than I'd prefer, but aside from that, it's a quiet neighborhood. Not many people move in or out, so I have become accustomed to most of the residents. People generally keep busy with yard work and other daily tasks. In winter, we sled down a hill on our side street. We live in a house on the front corner of our street, so we see everyone coming and going all day and recognize the cars people drive around here. Whenever we notice a strange vehicle, we usually pay attention to it. Some neighbors go walking for exercise or to walk their dogs. Kids ride their bikes, which is what you'd expect. We are often at home since we work from our house. There are four of us: myself, my wife, and our two daughters, who are eleven and fourteen years old. So, I'd say everyone else is used to us coming and going too. We go outside and play, sometimes even in the rain. Occasionally, we grill on our back deck, and the barbecue has a pleasant smell. It often seems like someone is mowing their lawn here, and you can hear a lawnmower nearly every day from March until around October when the grass finally stops growing. Our neighborhood has many trees because it was originally a wooded area, so there's plenty of shade, but there are also many leaves in the fall. This means raking and burning leaves annually. I like the smell of burning leaves too, so it's always a nice sign that fall has arrived. Recently, we haven't had much of a winter, so it feels more like a long fall. Our garage is at the back of our house, so we rarely use the front door unless someone knocks, which is uncommon. I enjoy working on my truck or other projects in the garage sometimes, and when I have the garage doors open, I feel more connected to the neighborhood. On holidays, it's quite peaceful here. During Thanksgiving, some neighborhood families have visitors from out of town, and there are extra cars parked everywhere at that time of year. It's similar during other holidays like Mother's Day and Christmas. Overall, I enjoy living here. If it weren't a through street, it would be perfect.

My neighborhood is located right in the center of the high desert, where there's nothing but dirt, dirt, and more dirt. Unless someone has actually lived here, they might not fully understand the constant sight of brown, and when you do see a lawn, you know that person is spending a fortune on lawn maintenance. When I first lived here in the 90s, houses were quite far apart. Now, it's mostly the same, but there are plenty of new additions. Honestly, this place resembles a city more and more each day, but I suppose most areas are changing in a similar fashion. Most of the people are very friendly, but like any city, there are good parts and bad. In my neighborhood, I'm surrounded by friendly elderly folks, so I guess it's a nicer area. The stores here are mostly chain stores like Food 4 Less and Smart & Final. If you're looking for upscale options, you have to travel; I never really see any Whole Foods or similar stores. The most common jobs in my city, as far as I can tell without any official demographics, are in construction. I believe this is because the city is still not very developed, with lots of open spaces left to build on. That kind of worries me because I like things as they are now. I left a big city and I'm not interested in going back. Speaking of construction, that's the field of my full-time job; I'm a drywall and T-bar installer. What I enjoy about my home is the variety of animals. People come to the high desert for many reasons, including the stark beauty of the desert itself. The high desert climate and landscape have created challenging ecosystems that need protection and are home to various types of wildlife. Human residents of the high desert should take time to learn about the non-human residents who share this environment to coexist safely and harmoniously. My family and I have adapted well to the wildlife. I have three children, and they are all fascinated by lizards and desert bugs; as I'm writing this, they're outside trying to catch different specimens. Regarding attractions, we have some. Additionally, Victorville is a good place for families to experience the desert. It can offer a unique experience. If possible, plan your visit to coincide with its annual event: the San Bernardino County Fair. The fair will enrich your visit with the right mix of activities and fun in the Victorville way. Visit the nearby Wrightwood to see the snow-covered mountains and take some winter sports lessons to round out your visit. Interested in the natural history and culture of the high desert ecosystem? The Victor Valley Museum includes geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that tell the story of Victorville's development in society and industry.

When asked to describe my neighborhood, my response is likely unique. Unlike others who might be homeowners leading their own lives, my situation is a bit different. I think of my neighborhood as the college campus where I live, with the people in my dormitory being my community. I also consider the surrounding campus as part of my neighborhood, though to a lesser degree. Despite this peculiarity, my neighborhood shares similarities with traditional neighborhoods. Like any typical neighborhood, the one I live in has houses, people, stores, and parks. Let's start by talking about the "houses" that make up my neighborhood. Before diving into the houses, it's helpful to clarify the types found here. There are three kinds of housing nearby: apartments, actual houses, and dormitory houses. First, in the apartments, there are usually 2-4 people per room, with about 4-6 rooms on each floor. The most common building type has about 2 floors, so roughly 20 people live in each building on average. Second, there are actual houses available for anyone affiliated with the school to rent, typically 2-4 bedroom setups often occupied by alumni. However, there are only a few of these scattered around, as they are less efficient. Finally, there are standard dorm rooms housing hundreds of students. These usually have two people per room, with some exceptions, and this is the most common housing in my neighborhood. With housing covered, we can move on to the people. My school prides itself on diversity, reflected in the makeup of my neighborhood. People from all cultures and ages live here. Most professional staff reside in neighborhood houses, while newer students stay in dormitory-style housing and older students in apartment-style housing. Simply talking about the people doesn't capture them fully, so let's move on to the stores and parks. As my school is essentially a self-contained neighborhood, it has a range of stores and a single park. The stores mix dining options found in any neighborhood with the school’s unique clothing and grocery stores. So, anything needed can be found within the neighborhood! Additionally, the park is a playground for all the diverse people here, kept clean and safe by the community!

There aren't many sidewalks where I live. Everything seems to slope downwards, and my house is right at the top of the steepest hill in the neighborhood. People call it the "workout hill" because so many joggers like to run up it during their daily exercise. Since there aren't any sidewalks on my street, everyone walks on the road. The road is uneven in places and can feel a bit hazardous to drive on. Some of the telephone and power lines strung around the block look tattered. It rains and storms a lot in our area, so branches and other debris often hit the power lines, and the constant repairs make them look patchy and piecemeal. There are many tall evergreen trees everywhere you look. But people here dislike the trees. They try to cut down as many as possible because the trees block the view of the ocean. That's why many houses are built high up on the hill, with huge glass-fronted second floors that rise up one after the other to take in the view of the bay. It's beautiful around sunset when the water seems to be lit from below and the sky turns orange. However, it's often cloudy, so you mostly see the sunlight through a haze. Most days are overcast and damp. Moss grows on everything it can: roofs, cars, and railings. I once left my car parked in my driveway for a month, and when I went to use it, it had turned green and furry with moss. It took me three hours to scrape it all off. There aren't many children around where I live, though there's a school just a few blocks away. Most of the people in my neighborhood are older, many of them retired. Instead of kids, people have dogs. It's common to see them sitting on people's lawns or racing down the street after each other. If you leave a door or window open, you risk them sneaking into your house. I once found one in my living room and had to shoo it back out the front door. Rabbits run wild around the area. Some of them are quite large, and the gardeners hate them because they dig up the roots of plants and burrow into people's lawns. However, my cats love them and have hunted most of them out of our neighborhood. We also get the usual assortment of birds: small sparrows and hummingbirds, and occasionally a hawk or eagle flies by until the neighborhood crows chase it away. There aren't any stores nearby, but if you hike downhill to the waterfront, there are a few restaurants that serve fresh seafood. There isn't much of a beach down there, but the rocks along the shore are fun to throw into the water. The bay itself isn't very wide. You can see the opposite shoreline clearly even through the mist on most days.

If you're planning to visit Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, you won't have a hard time finding it! Public transportation is very accessible and is one of the most popular means of getting around in New York City. Bensonhurst is quite an urban neighborhood, so you'll still feel like you're in New York City. During your visit, be prepared to see various Asian stores all around. Over the past two decades, Bensonhurst has seen an influx of Asian residents. Because of this, you'll see an Asian-owned store on nearly every block as you walk. Supermarkets and laundromats are especially popular. Interestingly, these businesses are favored by locals because the quality of food in the supermarkets is excellent, prices are much cheaper, and it's very convenient. Just near where I am, there are four Asian supermarkets within a two-minute walking distance from each other. This adds to the convenience of grocery shopping. I'm not saying that Bensonhurst is solely populated by Asian residents. The area is quite diverse overall, with immigrants and their first- and second-generation American children present. Most of the large and popular businesses locally are Asian-owned. In addition to these Asian-owned businesses, there's also a recently renovated park nearby featuring about ten basketball courts, a large field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a playground for kids, and even a water fountain for children to enjoy in the summer. Since we're in New York City, of course, the parks are very diverse. You'll see all kinds of diversity here, with people getting along well. In this neighborhood, there aren't many large corporate buildings. The only buildings you'll find are for co-op living or condominium apartments. However, most of the living spaces here are two-family houses. Most people are quite friendly, but very noisy. Every day, you'll hear cars blasting their music as they drive past your house, or constantly revving their engines, which will wake you up in the morning. If you plan to visit at night, you should stay alert. This neighborhood is fairly safe, but people can be unpredictable. You might encounter people looking to cause trouble without reason, bullies, and thieves. I've been bullied in this neighborhood in the past through physical assault, but that was many years ago. A recent incident involved package theft. Although it's common, there are package thieves in this neighborhood. Lastly, although New York City fines people for not cleaning up after their dogs, people here don't follow the rules. Every morning, you'll see at least one dog mess on your way to the train station or supermarket. My biggest annoyance is dog waste on the sidewalks everywhere I go in this neighborhood. Be careful and keep your shoes clean!

The first thing to understand about Portland, Oregon, is what "weird" means. The unofficial town slogan, painted on the back of a building that acts as a pizza place, bar, music venue, and strip club—skirting the law on at least half of these activities—is "Keep Portland Weird". To some, it's a reminder of the Portland of the '90s and early 2000s—a city that was less known, less expensive, and a hotspot for creative and unique subcultures. For others, it's an invitation—come to Portland, where being called weird is now a compliment. Despite the influx of affluent Californians and the constant building of condos to house them, Portland remains weird. Weird doesn't always mean accepting, but it does mean embracing things that are often not accepted. Being weird doesn't mean lacking modern conveniences or challenges. Like the rest of the country, we buy most of our goods from China. There are countless ways to be weird, to be different, but Portland also has a lot of normalcy. Portland has yoga, hipsters, and business professionals. Perhaps being weird means taking all of this less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many in Portland, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers, herbs, and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in summer. Free boxes are usually cardboard with items someone is discarding, but they can also be plastic bags or containers. Often, they hold something magical, a perfect find for the passerby. They typically contain clothes and books, but can have anything. The magical potential of walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about, for me at least, but I'm just one type of weird among many. Some people I live with would never dream of picking their clothes from a box on the sidewalk. Those people might go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with live goats) or attend Timbers matches (the local soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all sorts of things, who pursue their dreams, or dream about pursuing their dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug issues often stem from mental health problems, and the constant rain much of the year, plus gloomy clouds, seems to contribute. Portland also has a homelessness issue, which nobody seems to know how to solve. The homeless population is drawn by the social services Portland offers, better than in most parts of the country, but our services are inadequate, like everywhere. The non-homeless population fluctuates between empathy and frustration. In this, we are not weird at all.

The mountains are ever-present. In the north, they bear witness to the sun's journey at every dawn and dusk. Regardless of how often I forget about them or how immersed I am in work and life to notice them, they remain, steadfast, unchallenged, and undisturbed by life's trials. On days when I am most stressed and tense, they demand to be seen, and when I turn to them, they allow my anxious soul to find rest, giving me the strength to carry on, day by day. I moved here when I started my undergraduate studies, and it was the mountains north of the campus that first captivated me. Sure, the university has its own breathtaking sights in its buildings, ponds, and trees, which have also captured my heart, but it is the mountains that truly hold their throne. The rest of the town is beautiful in its own way. There are countless cafés that have been home to many hours of caffeine-fueled cramming. You can walk or take the bus a little further to the downtown area and be enveloped in an aura of antiquity by the faded bricks lining the restaurants and office buildings. Here, this seemingly suburban town shows as much hustle and vigor as its neighboring urban city. However, this doesn't last for many blocks, as you can once again escape to the serene small town by passing the library. This proximity of different atmospheres gives this city a wondrous vibe, as if inviting exploration. With this, creating cherished memories is easy, each linked to a specific part of town. Whether it's walking past the rusty swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or running through the bustling downtown to catch a movie at the fancy theater for which the university provided tickets. Yet, it is also home to many harsh memories, as all places in life are bound to be. The ponds, in particular, can be quite fitting for reflection as well as crying sessions at two in the morning in the midst of an existential crisis, of which I have more experience. While watching the turtles, ducks, and insects live out their lives, each contributing or playing a role, I couldn't help but ponder my own sense of purpose as I struggled to navigate this mystery called life. So, I walked past the pond, the park, and the little houses that scream suburbia until I reached a main street. It was then that the sun shone its brilliant rays atop the palm trees, painting the sky along the way, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, there they were, as they had always been. The mighty, overwhelming mountains brushed against the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building on the horizon, and as if speaking without words, they stirred in me a sense of perseverance.

At first glance, you might overlook it—after all, it's a residential area behind a shopping strip, not a place where you'd expect people to live. At least, not places most would choose. But if you walk past the old, abandoned Whole Foods and go behind the hotels that are only occupied annually, except for a few summer stays for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. In these communities, on these streets, are a few apartment complexes—meticulously placed next to each other like Russian nesting dolls that have been carefully taken apart and lined up piece by piece down the road. The first apartments you'll encounter have been in the news for some rather unsavory dealings, so we won't focus too much on those—appearances can be deceiving, after all. But the apartments next to that complex, and the two complexes beside them, are a whole different world that almost no one in the area knows about. Across from these complexes is a community college's satellite campus—a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing guard by the road, where students trickle in, coffee in hand, yawning at 7 AM to start their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to let them in one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for causing traffic delays on days when attendance is higher. The road intersects with another residential street, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones under unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture and a lazily spinning ceiling fan churning the warm, thick summer air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, doing cartwheels and spinning across the prickly green blades while bees lazily circle the flower patches by the road. Retired folks walk their dogs on the path, frowning at teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls gathered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There's a sushi place in a strip mall by the park that offers inexpensive food but never seems too busy—a swimming supply store right next to it, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken—all the charm of a strip mall. There's also a frozen yogurt place, one of the DIY kind, and you often see teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they perform tricks on their skateboards and vape because they think it's the coolest thing. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana—a piece of history in the sleepy South where hardly anything changes, not even time.

My neighborhood is quite interesting. Most of the houses are single-family homes, but a few have been divided into two while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My house has a small yard in the front and a small driveway on the left side. Like most others, it reminds you of a time not too long ago when suburban living was the American dream. This dream once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now it seems to be slipping away. However, my neighborhood and many others still remain, still reaching out to us and those who visit, showing that the dream is still alive, and we hold onto it as best we can. People aren't as optimistic as they used to be, the maintenance of the little yards isn't what it used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, and the youth still play as if the world around them was their entire existence. The public school that has been here for nearly 90 years still stands, continuing to inspire a future in today's youth while stirring nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still bustling. All the homes look different but feel the same. There's a large supermarket called Super "A" owned by a large Yemeni family, who are possibly the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide, and kids usually play football, only pausing to let cars pass. Most people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and can tell stories of a past where everyone knew each other. There used to be a karate school, but when Hollywood stopped making Karate Kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the Karate Kid, so it's now a pharmacy, because, as they say, drugs make everything better. There's also a small movie theater that shows old movies at a discounted price, avoided by the youth because of its lack of new releases, but appreciated by the elders who think it's a small price for a night out, without the kids, of course. An expressway runs through my town, though the exits are in the neighboring town. There was once a petition to have an exit for our town. The youth supported it, but the elders opposed it. They believed that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, and they eventually convinced the city council to reject the request. A new high school is being built, and we're trying to decide on a mascot for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be the best representation of my town.

Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is highly diverse. Residential areas are seemingly randomly interspersed with commercial areas where various businesses operate. Some of these businesses are offices, while others include different shops, restaurants, and entertainment venues. There is no shortage of new restaurants to try or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known brands owned by major corporations, small boutiques are also gaining popularity. They are not only found in various malls but also line the streets, often within walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene if not surrounded by so many attractions. There are also a few nearby parks, and I've noticed that people often visit these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, there is quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small area, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a group of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. A little further outside my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of different races and origins, although they are sometimes divided into their own small communities within the city. We have areas known as Korea Town, China Town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are just a few miles away. However, even a short distance can mean a very long drive. Driving just 10 miles can sometimes take two hours due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere. While certain places of interest are inevitably nearby, the city is vast, and people generally do not prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and finding parking can be difficult almost anywhere. Ironically, there has been a lot of construction in recent years as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in and more vehicles on the roads. However, there are many different types of houses in my city. Not everyone lives or wants to live in a large apartment building. Residential areas consist of houses of various sizes, as well as smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others have duplexes. This is true even in my immediate neighborhood, so there is also a variety of housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of different ages, and to be perfectly honest, I don't know most of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor and a few other friends from the neighborhood who were all around my age.

"Where is everything?" she asked as we drove past the cornfields filling the horizon. "This is it!" I said, aware she'd be shocked by the sparseness of the open landscape. She came from a town where the grocery store was just a five-minute walk from her home—she had never seen so much open space before. Overwhelmed by the ubiquity of cornfields, I shared with her what it was like growing up in rural Ohio, and at that moment, she finally understood who I was and where I came from. Driving down the two-lane country road, you'll reach a quarry filled with water. Just beyond it is the small development where I live. The houses are mostly made of brick and stucco. Each house has at least half an acre of land, which everyone takes pride in maintaining. In spring, the annually planted flowers are abundant, along with the Midwestern trees that change with each season. The driveways are filled with the most luxurious Mercedes Benz cars, shining in the midday sun after a good old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road to my gray stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He spends the entire day mowing his lawn, and you can hear him singing over the hum of his mower. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he's always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He's grown older and lost some of his wit with age. In the past, he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deere Zero Turn mower. Finally, you reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and chased by our Terrier. Out back, there's a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and occasionally the "moo" from nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. This is where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to 'hunting' animals (mostly chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood kid available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet nothing is more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once held vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. With occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I often fought as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We'd build massive igloo-like forts to store our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland, we played pretend during a time when nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.

original_texts:
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
The general area in which I live in can be described as your typical cookie cutter suburbia. For my neighborhood in particular, the presence of a homeowner's association is very apparent. Upon entering, you'll see nothing but well-maintained single family homes, which we can thank the homeowner's association for. The front yards are all very similar. There's a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and rather short driveways. Every so often you'll see small trees as well. Everyone has a two car garage. As you continue to drive along throughout the neighborhood you'll see newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition. You won't find any potholes or anything like that here. Most of the houses are single story, but sometimes you'll see two stories as well. We don't have a typical mailbox set-up that you would expect for single family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house. Instead, it's more like apartments where there are a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street. Everyone uses a key to gain access their specific mailbox. And there's two larger lockers for packages. Again, you can thank the HOA and their obsession with uniformity for this. The location of my house is on the extreme edge of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburbs. As a result, we have a lot of land for, well, everything. There's multiple community pools to which anyone living here can access. It's well maintained and gated. And then there are various walking trails where you can walk your dog, or just go for an evening stroll by yourself. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise in. The neighborhood is large enough that you can simply run around it and get more than enough exercise. Most of the community is made up of retired people. It's a very safe area, and everyone looks out for one another. Mixed in with that, we have a small amount of middle aged and young professionals too. In regards to the city, it's surprisingly large - at least by population - but also has a small time town feel. We have the vast majority of amenities that you come to expect and rely on. For example, we have a exactly one mall. It's not huge, but it gets the job done. For me, it takes around 15 minutes of driving to get anywhere significant, but once I do that, I am greeted with many different stores to choose from. We have everything from high end grocery stores where you can get organic food, to bargain outlets that only stock a small selection of items and has bare minimum staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We have a lot of nice things, like pools and walking trails. And although we aren't right next door to any sort of shopping, you can just hop in a car and go to any major chain that you'd like.
The first time I'd heard of my place, I was listening to a podcast about people who'd gone missing. It was a little surprising. Almost every apartment in the area was going for over a thousand dollars a month. I'd never heard anything about that story and neither had any of my friends. Maybe it's the struggle. I know a few of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Things are expensive, but we've learned how to be frugal over the years. You start to like the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. You smell a lot less in adulthood. You might start to smoke, or you might just be too accustomed to the state of things. But the flea market always asserts itself. The smell of adulthood is dusty magazines stacked on a closed piano. It wedges itself in the leather and stays in even after you wash it. Here, there're 3 thrift stores in walking distance. If you start on the far side, you can patronize two charity thrifts, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is dense, cars and people fill the streets every morning, but you'd never hear it in the thrifts. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the store is silent. It's a nice place to lose an afternoon. Every year, there's more and more of those. Cars and people flood it. It's a developing city, they say. Headquartering one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery, it's still showing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everything and everyone is set on their own goals, and there isn't a whole lot anyone asks from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you alone. It's not like the South, where being a little concerned means you care. You don't pry into anyone's life here, really. You can keep up your shell as long as you'd like, and the city will crash and roll back like waves on the beach. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always something going on. In a way, we have less of an apartment of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors and they treat me pretty well. I try to make sure to clean after myself and leave them food and they do the same in kind. I bring mail to them and they to me. It's nice to see them and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I didn't totally ruin my life.
I live in a small Midwestern town that is just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood, on the east side of the town, could be described as the most economically disadvantaged area of the town. Property values are low, with most houses being rented to or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who will smile and say hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates, while slightly higher than other parts of town, are still generally low. There have been a few violent crimes in the past ten years within a few blocks of my home, including a few shootings and at least one homicide. Our next door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside an area bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime other than having an occasional item disappear from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. In general, the town in which I live has been profoundly affected by the “opioid epidemic” that has affected many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive attributes. My son’s elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite having special needs, he has not faced any bullying thus far due to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town’s population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, so that no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as “less than” due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable.
